I managed to get past this error by doing the follow (copied from here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50345987/xamarin-waiting-for-runtime-checks-to-complete-and-vs-emulator): 

    1) Build and Run the application 
    2) The build will stall with at "Waiting for Runtime Checks" 
    3) In the emulator click the ">>" arrows in the tool-bar to the right 
    4) Make a note of the IP address for the Windows Phone Emulator Internal Switch 5)
    5) Back in VS. From the menu select Tools->Android->Android ADB Command Prompt 
    6) Type "adb connect [IP_FROM_STEP_#4]" 

The build continued.

items.body_markdown:
I have a Fortran code structured as below that calls C vectorized functions. I want to know the correct way to parallelize this code with OpenMP in order to avoid creating redundant threads for the loops inside the functions. I wrote a working version that uses "parallel for" before each for loop, but this version creates threads each time the functions are called, which is about billions of times, and I want to minimize the overhead of creating/destroying threads many times.

For this, I put the parallel region in the loop of the main program for routine sub1, the only one that needs parallelization. My doubt is if the subroutines and vectorized functions will be unnecessarily executed by each thread. How to make only the for loops run in parallel with threads created/destroyed in main program?

If you need more information about the code, please let me know.



    program main

    it=0
    do while(it < nt)
        call sub0()
        !$omp parallel
        call sub1()
        !$omp end parallel
        call sub2()
        it=it+1
    end do

    end program main

    subroutine sub1()
        t=0 ! this variable is global, so threadprivate is used in the Fortran module
        do while(t < dt)
            call sub1a(t0)
            call sub1b()
            t=t+t0
        end do
    end subroutine sub1

    subroutine sub1a()
        vecsub1ainC(vars) ! call to vectorized C function
        compute t0 with vars
        do more computations
    end subroutine sub1a

    vecsub1ainC(vars)
    {
        // loop vectorized with Intel intrinsics
        #pragma omp for
        for(i=0;i<n;i++)
        {
            do computations with vars
        }
    }

    subroutine sub1b()
        vecsub1binC(vars) ! call to vectorized C function
        do more computations
    end subroutine sub1b

    vecsub1binC(vars)
    {
        // loop vectorized with Intel intrinsics
        #pragma omp for
        for(i=0;i<n;i++)
        {
            do computations with vars
        }
    }
items.title: How to parallelize C vectorized loops inside routines called from a parallel region in Fortran

answers.body_markdown:
I see a few issues: 

1. A perception activation shouldn't be ````tanh()````. If you use that, you will have to make sure to compute the gradients appropriately. But you can replace the activation by
````
double activationFunction(double sum)
{
    return sum > 0;
}
````
This will return 1 if sum > 0, otherwise it returns 0. 

2. When updating weights, ````biasValue```` should also be updated,as the perceptron needs to learn its value from your training data. You can update it using
````
biasValue += error * learningRate;
````

These changes will allow the perceptron to learn the AND gate.

items.body_markdown:
I was able to solve this myself with some code from another report in our company. Thank you to anyone who took a look.

***************************

We are using Microsoft SQL Server 2016.

I have a history table like such:

    hMy    DtOccurred    Unit    Tenant    Event    MoveOutDt    MoveInDt

Facts:
 
- `hMy` is a unique handle for each record
- `dtOccurred` is the datetime of the record creation
- `Unit` is the unit ID
- `Tenant` is the tenant ID
- `Event` is the type of record: 'Move Out' 'Move In' 'Rent Change' 'Adjust Move Out Dates' 'Notice of Move Out' 'Eviction' 'Lease Sign' etc
- `MoveOutdt` is the datetime of the anticipated or actual moveoutdt and can be null if the tenant is current and does not plan to move out, otherwise this date is repeated in each record if there is a planned move out date.
- `MoveInDt` is same as MoveOut but is the Move In date, repeated in each record, unless Event = 'Cancel Move In' or 'Application Cancelled'

I need to create a report with `#FromDate#` and `#ToDate#` inputs, that will then pull any units that have had a vacancy during that time, and then tell me the vacancy start date and vacancy end date. If the unit has had more than one period of vacancy during the date range, I need to pull all instances.

So I'm thinking something along the lines of: Find all records for each unit where Event like 'Move Out', 'Eviction', or 'Adjust Move Out Dates', use the `MoveOutDt` from the last record that matches the above criteria for each Tenant AS `VacancyStartDt`.

Then find the next occurrence where Event = 'Move In' and use MoveInDt AS VacancyEndDt. If there is no next MoveInDt (ie, unit is still vacant), then use the input #ToDate# instead.

So, my report would have inputs: `#FromDate#` : `#ToDate#`

And it would pull all units where VacancyStartDt or VacancyEndDt BETWEEN #FromDate# and #ToDate#

And it would give me:

* `Unit, VacancyStartDt, VacancyEndDt` for each vacancy period in the range.

I hope this is enough information to help me. I am a self-taught beginner in SQL, so I apologize for any ignorance on my part. There are more columns and more tables available, so if there's some type of information that would make this easier, let me know and I can look for such a field. Thank you! -Amanda

There is no short or obtuse code for this, indeed not if holidays should be taken into account.

One example is my function here: [DateDiffWorkdays][1].

However, all you need is to copy-paste the full code into a new module, compile, and save.

Then, to check, use an expression similar to this in the *Format* event of the *Details* section of the report:

~~~vba
Private Sub Detailsection_Format(Cancel As Integer, FormatCount As Integer)

    Me!YourTextbox.ForeColor = IIf(DateDiffWorkdays([OrderDate],Date()) > 3, vbRed, vbBlack)

End Sub
~~~


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56630108/why-does-my-calcworkingdays-vba-function-give-me-two-different-results-on-the-sa/56631139#56631139

answers.body_markdown:
Combine `sort` and `uniq -c` like this:

    /bin/ls -c1 *<STRING>* | sort | uniq -c

or use this to recurse into sub-directories:

    find . -type f -name "*<STRING>*" -print | sort | uniq -c

<br>
The `sort` is required since `uniq -c` collapses identical adjacent lines into one, and the `-c` option adds the number of collapsed lines.

The tutorial you are following is out of date, Check the [docs][1] and this official [tutorial][2]

Base64 just return the base64 data, that can’t be displayed in an img tag as you have figured out.

But there is DataUrl result type, which returns a proper data url you can use to display in the img tag.

answers.body_markdown:
Checkout SourceCode on https://github.com/ionic-team/capacitor/blob/fc1150a1d2fe15d2ece34507c1deae4eb8b6b028/core/src/web/camera.ts#L46

If you specify resultType: CameraResultType.Uri

The plugin Will [URL.createObjectURL(PhotoBlob)][1]

(*aprox: Take the PhotoBlob and create a url that Will serve it from memory)
So you only have to atach that to the src of the img.


If you use [FileReader.readAsDataURL()][2] The plugin Will read the camera stream and produce a Base64 data url like (data:content.typeOfImage/base64) that you could also put on src field, then the img Will decode the string and render it.

If you use CameraResultType.Base64 The plugin Will read the camera stream and produce only the base64 string not the data url. If you know the content-type of the image you could produce the data url by concatenation and have (data:content.typeOfImage/base64).


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/createObjectURL
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileReader/readAsDataURL

answers.body_markdown:
The dashes in your "−−no−same−owner" string are UTF-8 [unicode minus][1] characters:

    % echo '−−no−same−owner' | od -t x1c
    0000000    e2  88  92  e2  88  92  6e  6f  e2  88  92  73  61  6d  65  e2
               −  **  **   −  **  **   n   o   −  **  **   s   a   m   e   −
    0000020    88  92  6f  77  6e  65  72  0a                                
              **  **   o   w   n   e   r  \n                                
    0000030

"e2 88 92" is the UTF-8 encoding of U+2212, the minus sign.

Tar is isn't recognizing "−−no−same−owner" as a command-line option because it doesn't start with the [ASCII dash][2] which normally marks command-line options. It's treating it as a filename instead.

Maybe you copied and pasted "−−no−same−owner" from a word processing document?


  [1]: https://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/2212/index.htm
  [2]: https://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/002d/index.htm

answers.body_markdown:
## This data has issues:

### Fix the data:

 - Using `converters={'surface_distance': eval}` or `ast.literal_eval` will not work because all the rows of data are not properly enclosed with `[]` at both ends.
 - This is a full solution, working with the data as it's provided in the Excel file.
 -  After the format of `surface_distance` is fixed, use [.`explode()`][1], to separate the lists
  - This function works on a `pandas.Series`, therefore set the index to `LTP`, so each `surface_distance` value is properly assigned to its corresponding `LTP` value.

```python
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def fix_my_data(x):
    x = x.replace('[', '').replace(']', '').strip().split(',')
    return [float(v.strip()) for v in x if v not in ['', ' ']]

# import the data
df = pd.read_excel('surface.xlsx')

# rename the column
df.rename(columns={'SurfaceDistances_Tumor2Ablation': 'surface_distance'}, inplace=True)

# create a valid list of numeric values
df.surface_distance = df.surface_distance.apply(fix_my_data)

# set index to LTP
df.set_index('LTP', inplace=True)

# pandas version 0.25 use explode to expand all lists
# update pandas if you're not on 0.25
df_sd = df.surface_distance.explode().rename_axis('LTP').reset_index(name='sd')

sns.boxplot(x='LTP', y='sd', data=df_sd)
plt.show()
```

[![enter image description here][2]][2]


  [1]: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.25/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.explode.html
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/6DVMl.png

If you want to rotate an object around a pivot then you've to:

- Translate the object in that way that way, that the pivot is on the origin (0, 0, 0).  
  Since your object is located at (0, 1, 0) this means the object has to be translated by (0, -1, 0).

- Rotate the object. If the object has to be rotated in the projection plane to the screen, then the rotation axis has to be the z axis (0, 0, 1). If the object hast to be rotated around an vertical axis, then the rotation axis has to be the z axis (0, 1, 0). For a rotation around a horizontal axis, the object has to be rotated around the x axis (0, 1, 0).

- Translate the rectangle in that way that the pivot is back at its original position.  
  This means the object has to be translated by (0, 1, 0).

```lang-none
rotationMatrix = translate(0, 1, 0) * rotate * translate(0, -1, 0)
```       

You've to use the [Matrix](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/opengl/Matrix) operations `Matrix.translateM` respectively `Matrix.rotateM`, which create a new matrix and multiply the input matrix by the new matrix:

```java
private float[] rotationMatrix = new float[16];
```

```java
Matrix.setIdentityM(rotationMatrix, 0);

Matrix.translateM(rotationMatrix, 0, 0, 1, 0);
Matrix.rotateM(rotationMatrix, 0, 90, 0, 0, 1);
Matrix.translateM(rotationMatrix, 0, 0, -1, 0);
```

Note, the rotation axis are the last 3 parameters of `Matrix.rotateM`. You've to set them  for your needs.

answers.body_markdown:
`equiv(a, b)` in that requirement isn't a function.  It's just a logical construct used to specify what conditions must hold for a type to meet the Compare requirement.

That is, for an object of type `T` named `comp`, imagine a function named `equiv` that is equivalent to the expression `!comp(a, b) && !comp(b, a)`.  That hypothetical function would have to meet the outlined requirements, but it isn't actually a thing that exists.  It's just given as a way to specify how `comp` must behave.

---

Note that in your example, `A::operator<` does _not_ itself meet the Compare requirements (`A::operator<(a, b)` is not well-formed).  What's actually being used by `std::sort` is `std::less<A>`, which uses the expression `a < b` to do its actual comparison.  For `std::less<A>` to meet the Compare requirements the behavior of the expression `a < b` must specify a strict weak ordering, but it does not meet the Compare requirements itself.

But since O(n) is higher complexity than O(log n), then O(n) takes more precedence and the overall run time will be O(n).

answers.body_markdown:
> This currently works perfectly every time I open a .myextension file from my emulator.

It will fail much of the time, as it is not really tied to an emulator versus a device.

> However, when I try it from my device, it no longer works. 

A `content` `Uri` is not required to have a file extension, just as an `https` URL is not required to have a file extension. Much of the time, a `content` `Uri` will not have a file extension, and such a `Uri` will not match your `<intent-filter>`.

`ACTION_VIEW` is mostly for files with a widely-recognized MIME type. 

> I've also tried replacing that data tag/adding a second tag with this block but it doesn't seem to help

`file` `Uri` values have been generally banned since Android 7.0.

answers.body_markdown:
If you have an array of `TRefs`, you can use them directly as an integer index on the other collection. (See [this tutorial](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/jpivarski/2019-07-29-dpf-python/blob/master/03-columnar-data-analysis.ipynb), starting on `In[29]`, for a general introduction to indexing by integer arrays, both in Numpy and Awkward Array.)

That is, if you have an array of `TRef`, as in [this example][1],


```python
import uproot
t = uproot.open("issue324.root")["Delphes"]
refs = t["Track.Particle"].array()
refs.id
# <JaggedArray [
#      [752 766 780 ... 1813 1367 1666]
#      ...
#      [745 762 783 ... 1863 1713 1717]]>
```

gives you the indexes and

```python
pt = t["Particle.PT"].array()
```

the array you want to reference, so

```python
pt[refs.id - 1]
# <JaggedArray [
#      [0.7637838 1.1044897 5.463864 ... 4.252923 1.9702696 9.213475]
#      ...
#      [1.2523094 0.37887865 0.7390242 ... 1.0288503 3.4785874 1.804613]]>
```

selects the `pt` values of interest (correcting for the fact that these indexes start with `1` and Python indexes start with `0`).

If you have an array of `TRefArray` as in [this example][2],

```python
t["Tower.Particles"].array()
# <ObjectArray [[[1414, 1418, 1471, 1571], [1447], [1572],
#               ...,
#               [864, 1325], [992, 1437], [1262, 1501]]]>
```

it's actually an `ObjectArray` that generates sub-arrays from the data on demand (because ROOT doesn't store doubly jagged data natively). You can convert them to native `JaggedArrays` by calling `awkward.fromiter` on them:

```python
import awkward
a = awkward.fromiter(t["Tower.Particles"].array())
# <JaggedArray [[[1414 1418 1471 1571] [1447] [1572] 
#                ...
#                [864 1325] [992 1437] [1262 1501]]]>
```

and then use these doubly jagged indexes in any doubly jagged collection (in which all the numbers of elements line up, as they would for the collection you're referencing).



  [1]: https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/issues/324#issuecomment-526715265
  [2]: https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/issues/329#issuecomment-528417617

for clarity sake, change variable name in **config.py**:

    PATH_TO_CREDENTIALS = os.environ.get('GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS')


then, import `service_account` into your **video.py** module, like so:

    from google.oauth2 import service_account

and:
    
    GET_CREDENTIALS = DevelopmentConfig.PATH_TO_CREDENTIALS

Finally, pass credentials, like so:

    youtube = build(YOUTUBE_API_SERVICE_NAME, YOUTUBE_API_VERSION, credentials=PASS_CREDENTIALS,
        developerKey=None)

This will work.

answers.body_markdown:
Date values are basically the number of seconds since a particular date. Here we can calculate the week offset with a bit of modulo math

    df %>% 
      mutate(NewWeek = as.numeric(Date-min(Date)) %/% (60*60*24*7) + 1)

We subtract off the first date, then see how many seven day periods have passed.
answers.title: Can we extract week numbers from the date

answers.body_markdown:
You can use `lubridate`:

    library(lubridate)
    df$Data <- trunc((ymd(df$Date) - min(ymd(df$Date)))/dweeks(1)) + 1

`1` is needed to start numbering of weeks from 1. `trunc` gets rid of decimal places.

answers.body_markdown:
You're very close to get the solution. But I thin your error comes from here:
$data variable in your controller will be an array, so in your foreach body you got an error from here

    $row->item_name

So instead of this:

    $data = DB::table('items')
           ->where('item_name', 'LIKE', '%{$query}%')
           ->get();

Write this (assume that your model name is "Item"):

    $data = Item::where('item_name', 'LIKE', '%{$query}%')->get();

IMHO this will solve the problem. But this will return only case sensitive values. For example if you will type "abc", it will not return the words with "ABC". So for that you can just make 2 sides as uppercase and compare. Like this:

    $data = Item::whereRaw("UPPER(item_name) LIKE '%" . strtoupper($query) . "%'")->get();

If you want to go forward and search also the special characters, then I think this answer will be not only the answer of your question.
But at the this moment I recommend you to use the last row.

It sounds like you're discovering that putting a lot of app-related information into the regular IPC between the main process and render process(es) ends up with impacting app performance. James Long has written about this - https://jlongster.com/secret-of-good-electron-apps

Instead of using a hidden render window (BrowserWindow) to run your non-render code, think about forking the main process and running IPC to/from there.

answers.body_markdown:
In order to understand why this works fine on normal queries and not on projection queries you might want firstly to read about what is the actual difference between those two. As it is mentioned in this [post][1]:

> Whereas "regular" (which I'm taking to mean SELECT * ...) queries against Cloud Datastore typically use indexes that only contain a sorted subset of the properties of the queried entities, plus pointers to the full entities, projection queries run against indexes that contain all the fields requested by the query. So it appears the significant latency gain comes from the elimination of the need to fetch the queried entities once the set of entities matching the query has been discerned via the index.

So, basically, when you do your projection query, your queried entities are not fetched. 

As I was reading through this [official documentation][2], I found some really interesting phrases related to your question :

> 
A field of slice type corresponds to a Datastore array property, except for []byte, which corresponds to a Datastore blob. If a non-array value is loaded into a slice field, the result will be a slice with one element, containing the value.
> 

> Key Field
If the struct contains a *datastore.Key field tagged with the name "__key__", its value will be ignored on Put. When reading the Entity back into the Go struct, the field will be populated with the *datastore.Key value used to query for the Entity.

What I understood from here is that maybe in your case, the fields are populated with the key value for that query ( string ).

Another interesting thing that I have discoverd is that according to the [properties and values type documentation][3] the type []byte is not indexed. And as it is told [here][4], unindexed properties cannot be projected. So projected queries should not work for this particular use case at all.


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51780085/projection-queries-vs-regular-queries
  [2]: https://godoc.org/cloud.google.com/go/datastore#Property
  [3]: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/go/datastore/entities#Properties_and_value_types
  [4]: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/python/ndb/projectionqueries#Limitations_on_projections

answers.body_markdown:
Solved.

My problem is the WebSphere, that store an old version of the third party JAR.

    \was\wasprofiles\wp_profile80\installedApps\GUUPZN00Cell\MY-APP.ear\lib\LOGGER-LIB-1.0.0.jar
    \was\wasprofiles\wp_profile80\installedApps\GUUPZN00Cell\MY-APP.ear\lib\LOGGER-LIB-1.0.1.jar

The version "1.0.0" LOGGER-LIB doesn't  contains the bean "loggerManager" and WebSphere is loading this version of the library.
It seems that the file was blocked when websphere try to delete it. I had to stop the server to delete it properly.
